key_points: Hennepin County District Judge Peter Cahill released the names of jurors and two alternate jurors in Derek Chauvin's trial.
The release was in response to a media request led by The Associated Press for juror names and questionnaire responses.
Derek Chauvin was convicted of second-degree murder, third-degree murder, and manslaughter in the death of George Floyd.
Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer, was sentenced to 22 1/2 years for his actions.
The jurors' names were initially sealed due to concerns for their safety and privacy amid the high-profile case.
Prosecutors had opposed the release, fearing harassment of jurors and challenges in seating a jury for a related trial.
A media coalition argued for the release, citing the public and media's right to such information.
No known threats to jurors' safety were reported, influencing the decision to release their names.
Some jurors and an alternate had already identified themselves and spoken to the media.
The judge saw no strong reason to keep the jurors' names and questionnaire answers sealed.
